text: hello and welcome to cupcake addictions
billow puff cupcake tutorial where today
I'm going to be showing you how to
achieve this really cute kind of puffy
billowed technique using fondant that
you can use on your cakes and cupcakes
the things that you'll need for today's
tutorial have a little bit of cornflour
some of our perfectly pipeable
buttercream frosting and also one of our
red velvet cupcakes so I will leave a
link to both of those recipes in the
description box below I've got a little
bit of either fondant or modeling
chocolate some wax paper a pizza cutter
a knife a fondant roller and a
paintbrush and then I've just got some
little roundball sprinkles and of course
a little bit of plain tap water so let's
get started the first thing that you
want to do is you want to roll out your
fondant and roll it out really nice and
thin here because you don't want to have
too much fondant on top of these
cupcakes and the thinner you roll your
fondant the nicer kind of a billowed
puffy effect you're going to be able to
get all right now I've got my fondant
rolled out I'm going to pop that off to
the side and we're actually going to
cover that up with that wax paper with
fondant it starts to dry out when it's
exposed to the air and you want to try
and keep it away from the air as much as
possible so that just gives us a bit
more time to work with it all right so
you want to frost up your cupcake now
and you want to frost these cupcakes one
at a time before you put the pillow puff
technique on them this is because your
buttercream will start to form a little
bit of a crust and once it starts to
form a crust it's kind of hard to get
that fondant to stick to it so just
frost and then decorate with fondant and
then move on to the next one and frost
and decorate with fondant I just
scooping a nice amount of that frosting
onto the top and then using the back of
my knife just just shape it down into a
bit of a nice sort of a smooth dome but
don't make it too high because there's
going to be quite a lot going on and you
want a bit of height in those little
billowed finishes or those little puffy
finishes alright now from here you want
to cut kind of little strips out of your
fondant so just cut off one end so that
you've got a nice neat edge to work with
and make sure that you're cutting them
roughly the same width that's going to
give you a very similar sized below puff
but they don't have to be exactly
perfect now you want to just cut your
fondant into relatively even size
lengths here and mine are just a bit
bigger than an inch maybe an inch and a
half obviously if you're doing this
technique on a larger cake you can make
them larger will take a bit less time I
want my nice and small now you want
take your fondant and you can't afford
it accordion fold it so kind of squeeze
it together and then squeeze it together
again which gives you that really nice
kind of crinkled effect at either end
like so and then I'm using my middle
finger just to push out and kind of just
shape that over the finger a little bit
to give it that nice puffy effect before
grabbing either end and pushing either
end into that top frosting you want to
repeat that process again but what you
want to do here is you want to make sure
that each puff is kind of going over the
join of the puff before so pushing that
one down but you'll see that we've got
our nice little draw in there and then
the next puff kind of doesn't cover the
join but meets up with it and where
you've put your overhang on the sides
you can just take your knife and just
cut away you do want to make sure that
you can't see any of that white
buttercream frosting poking through but
don't worry at this point if your little
joints are not particularly neat because
that's where little ball sprinkles are
going to come in and we're going to be
able to fix those up and kind of
disguise them a bit alright so coming
into our last one and this has only
taken me probably about four or five
minutes so it's not that hugely
time-consuming and just use that just to
kind of cover in that last little
section but make sure you come around
the edges to make sure you're really
covering in all of that frosting and
there you've got your basic below
technique now these always look a little
bit messy until you go in and add your
little detail so this is where the
little balls are coming in you can use
silver ones you can use any really type
of sort of sprinkle or design little
flowers if you like but I'm going to go
with a contrasting color of these little
sugar pearls you just want to put a
little tiny dab of water just do the
center of the join and don't put too
much water here and use that just to
stick in so as you stick those little
balls and you'll see they're actually
going to kind of make an indentation
into your fondant which also helps your
little puff sections look like they're
puffing out just a little bit more but
more than that they're actually covering
up any of those little joins and creases
and making them all look like they're
part of one big piece of fabric this is
also a really great opportunity for you
to cover up any little bits of white
frosting that you may be able to see
peeking out the sides of your cupcake so
there you've got your finished billowy
puffy kind of fabric a looking cupcake
if you've love this tutorial make sure
that you head on over to my channel my
cupcake addiction and hit the subscribe
button for lots more cake decorating
cupcake decorating and kpop decorating
videos and as always thanks for
for tuning in to my jacket addiction
